eventName: one year since being diagnosed with breast cancer
story:
One year ago today (28 November) I was diagnosed with Breast Cancer at the age of 32. 

On top of the change and uncertainty of coronavirus I’ve battled cancer treatment to stay alive - for my husband, my daughters, my family and friends. 

In December 2019, I had a lumpectomy and lymph node biopsy. In January 2020, knowing it had started to spread, I had further breast tissue removed and a full lymph node clearance in my right arm. 

I narrowly missed chemotherapy as a result of some impressive genetic testing and in March, began 20 rounds of radiotherapy just as the country went into lockdown.

Now, I have monthly injections and daily tablets and await an operation to sterilise me to prevent the oestrogen eating cancer coming back again!  

EVERY step of the way a Macmillan Cancer Support nurse was there, to support me, to catch me, to explain things to me, to tell me my test results, to book my appointments. 

Cancer is the forgotten ‘C’ of 2020. Frightened patients of all ages are facing treatment alone because of COVID restrictions.

But the fortunate ones have a Macmillan nurse in their hospital. Some use the Macmillan website for clarification around alien words/procedures/medications, some pick up the phone and talk to a dedicated medical professional on the Macmillan helpline. 

All this - and more - is threatened by a lack of fundraising! 

I wanted to mark this day with an event to celebrate beating cancer. I wanted to give back to a charity whose love and expertise got me through. 

So please, spare a bit of your Christmas budget, buy one less coffee, and do something INCREDIBLE - donate to Macmillan! 

Thank you so much,

Kathryn

story:
Ang was diagnosed with cancer in her appendix and stomach lining at the end of feb. She was able to have chemotherapy for a short period but we were then told this was not working and the cancer was spreading. Despite the worry, the pain and discomfort mum took this in her stride and continued to always put others before herself and showed courage like we’ve never seen before.
Not only did mum have to deal with a terminal illness she had the added complications of COVID-19 meaning she had to attend all appointments/treatment alone and could not spend time with family/friends when she needed them the most.

On the 21st Oct Ang moved to St. Peter’s after spending 3 very difficult weeks at southmead. Mum was at the hospice for 2 weeks and in that time she received exceptional, attentive care from all of the staff at St. Peter’s hospice.
They assisted in creating an early Christmas Day for Mum which she loved and was a great moment for all the family.

Despite COVID restrictions the hospice still gave an incredible service to our family and we are eternally grateful for that. The staff also provided family support and comfort which made the very difficult time that little bit easier.

story:
Hi, My name is Andy Fraser and I am an Aerodrome Rescue and Fire Fighting Inspector for AAA.

Please read below and support this worthy cause.


The aircraft is a Spitfire Mk IXC in 1/32 Scale

The squadron markings are for 601 squadron with colour
markings used when they were based in Fano Italy in WW2.

 

The silver colour scheme is different to the more common
camouflage type, not sure why this is but I thought it might be more
interesting to do something different hence silver.

 

The war photographs researched seem to align with the scheme
however, they are not in colour consequently, its not possible to confirm the
colour of the nose section which, the manufacturer depicts as being camouflage
in its schematic.

The lack of wing tips are again my personal choice as it’s
different, this change is based on fact and was an initiative by some clever
engineering types in an attempt to further develop the product. The outcome from
removing these resulted in an increase in performance primarily manoeuvrability
in certain types of flight which allowed our pilots to match the later
generation aircraft developed by the opposition.

 

For those that are Spitfire enthusiasts there are a couple
or three of botches partly due to the due to the fragile manufacturing of
certain component parts and my heavy handedness i.e. the Starboard undercarriage
which I had to add some additional plastic in order to strengthen it otherwise
it would not have supported the airframe (perhaps a surveyor for that one). The
others I will leave you to try to spot?

 

The painting has been adjusted to show some light wear from
usage as i don’t like fresh of the production line models. My primary
requirement was to capture the fine detail that the model manufacturer has seen
fit to include i.e. rivets, seamlines etc.  

All parts of the model have been hand painted as I don’t
possess a sprayer, this makes it a tad more difficult as applying paint by brush
goes on much thicker than spraying. Consequently, I have used a dry brush
technique which sort of works along with various types of washes the latter
being diluted paint colourings)?

I am afraid its not a perfect example of model art if you’re
a collector but, as this is a charity event perhaps both you and R J Mitchell
(the aircraft designer) will forgive me for that. On the positive side you get
something to dust, take up space around the house and maybe undertake further
work on it?

I don’t normally do model aircraft as they are more
difficult than my preference which is armoured fighting vehicles. It was bought
by my daughter as she knows I like to keep busy when Neighbours and Coronation
Street are on the telly???  

The thought process for doing this came from various friends
(and there are a few) within the CAA that have had cancer or experienced the
loss of a family member who sadly succumbed to it.

story:
Up to a few years ago I had very little to do with Doctors & Medical professionals other than getting treated for sports injuries.However you never know what's around the bend.To summarise I was diagnosed with a rare form of blood cancer due to abnormalities in my bone marrow in May 2019.I am now disease free thanks to my Bone Marrow (Stem Cell) Transplant in January 2020.

In August 2020 I was diagnosed with Intermediate stage Prostate Cancer & had the operation to remove it in October 2020.During these situations Macmillan provide support & information to help come to terms with our new situation..

This time last year I was too weak to consider anything like this but as I'm recovering & getting stronger daily , I'm looking forward to this challenge.

If you can help us reach our target we'd be most grateful.

Thanks for  supporting my fundraising. Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, we’re right right there with you.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Ms Cantle our headteacher, the staff and our school dog Max are coming together to complete a 5km run for 10 consecutive days!

We are completing the Macmillan 10 day 5K challenge We are calling on you to support them and follow their progress using this JustGiving page and help them get through the dark mornings, cold, wet evenings alongside all their book marking and COVID duties. Cheer them along with your motivational messages.

Our target is £1000, please do all you can to help us achieve this significant milestone and make it a Christmas to remember for all the right reasons!

story:
As everyone, I have been affected by some form of cancer. This has come through multiple cases in other family members who have sadly not been able to beat the horrible 'C' word and I know so many people have lost many loved ones too.

It is rare that a family has not suffered losing someone or even having a family member diagnosed with cancer, so I do not need to explain what it feels like or how it does effect you, mentally and emotionally.

I have been creating content for around a year on youtube, and this year I began streaming on twitch. For a couple months, on and off I have been pondering whether to do a charity stream whether it be a couple hours, a 12-hour or more. I then stumbled across this fantastic programme which has been setup by Macmillan in order to support and aid those that are living with cancer.

I saw this as a great opportunity to do something I love doing, and doing it for the sole purpose of helping out others and for such a great cause.


The idea for this 24-hour stream would be first and foremost to raise money for Macmillan cancer support who do so much for the nations cancer patients and family members and they are doing an absolutely fantastic job that words cannot describe.


Secondly, this stream would be a place where people can come and talk to me about their issues, troubles, any worries that they have without having to feel embarrased or alone, because everyone has gone through difficult times and worrying times and sometimes talking to someone about these worries, issues, troubles or whatever it is can often make it better.


This stream will offer out a safe place for everyone and anyone to come and join, chill relax and take your mind off the world around you ESPECIALLY in these unprecedented times.


In order to keep this stream entertaining and exciting, I will be playing a plethora of games, taking on challenges and for the chances we hit any milestones for the fundraising I will be short to make a list of things I can do which will be sure to make you laugh and keep you amused throughout the 24-hour period.

story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support.

I will be holding raffles throughout December to raise funds for BHF by giving away various gifts I have either already painted or to be painted in a colour of your choice. All I am asking is £1-£2 per raffle ticket which would go a long way in helping some one from not dying unexpectedly like my nan recently did.

In honor of my late nan, Jessie I will be fundraising as much as I can so loved ones do not have to face living without someone so suddenly who has a heart condition. 

My nan had suffered several heart attacks which damaged her heart so badly without her knowing and she passed it off as indigestion, but she had an aneurism which caused her to suddenly be taking from us. She was fit and healthy on the outside throughout her life up until recent. She would be out every day doing something, to see her friends at the pop Inn, doing her shopping in the local town centre from the minute she woke or seeing her eldest brother to take him some sweet treats on a Friday. But when the lockdown happened, she became a shell of her true self and wouldnt step on a bus at all. Her anxiety sky rocketed and as much as we tried to help her get out, she would only travel local by car. Also due to the lockdown and her not getting out as usual, she put on the weight that she had lost and it had put a strain on her heart. She would fall asleep several times in the day, even while we were visiting. The doctors didn't see low oxygen levels but her blood pressure was low. Nothing was checked over thoroughly but she suffers from high blood pressure so that should have rung alarm bells for them. It was only when she suffered chest pains one night that she was taking into hospital where they found her heart was so badly damaged that one more heart attack would be the end of life for her. Being very reserved as she was, she never let us know that and 2 days later she suddenly passed. We weren't able to visit while she was in hospital so it was hard to accept. The condition she died from is rare and can be hereditary, so we will hope to be checked ourselves in the near future. 

Anyone could have a heart condition they are unaware of and so it is so important that more awareness of them is spread. Please help if you can, to maybe save mine or your life next time.

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thank you!

story:
The 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas Collection 

Help us as we aim to raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs this Christmas! 

During December the four-legged volunteers of the Cotswolds Oxfordshire Fundraising Group would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at collections and events in your community.  

Due to the current situation, we’re not able to be out as much this 
festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships!  

It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas.  

We appreciate that times are difficult, but for people with sight loss, 
social isolation can be their everyday. You can help them feel less alone, now and in the future. 

Don’t forget to send it on through Facebook, WhatsApp, email or text and get your friends and family involved too. 

Thank you and Merry Christmas!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Hi, welcome to my just giving page. As many of you may be aware I lost my most wonderful mum 7 years ago this year. She was a true inspiration to me, she helped me become the person I am now. She was such a fighter but she couldn't fight the horrible cancer any more. On the 1st of December 2020 this wonderful women would have been turning 60. There is not a day that goes by where I wish with all my heart that she was here, now bringing my own little one into the world in a matter of months, I just felt now was time to do some more fundraising.


Also more recently my wonderful cousin Keri has been diagnosed with cancer, she is such a fantastic and up beat person who I believe will get the better of this horrible illness, she is a true inspiration to us all and taking the cancer head on and with her big smile on her face ❤️❤️❤️❤️. So please support her in her time of need, so my fundraising is for her and family too.

 It has been a hard year for charities with this horrible COVID around and much fundraising has been not been able to be carried out. As Cancer research covers both mine and Keri’s common goal that’s who I will be fundraising for.

Now with current restrictions in place it is quite hard to find something I can do but within the restrictions we have on us. My choice is to dye my hair pink(or as close to pink as I can get it without going to the hairdressers). My wonderful wife has decided she is going to complete the deed for me (mainly so I can’t run away from it, wish me luck). I will be using semi permanent dye so for next month it will be definitely there to see. I will be doing on mums birthday 1/12/2020. It will be a reminder to myself that cancer is always effecting someone so each morning I see my hair a different colour will be a reminder that there is always someone out there suffering from this horrible illness.  

So please donate as much as you can, if you would rather pay in cash or another means feel free to contact me.

Thanks in advance, and thanks for the help and support you all have given me and my family over the last 7 years.

Love you mum

Ps Mum I hope you approve of the colour ❤️❤️

Let's work together to celebrate Tony's life and the huge positive impact he has had on us all. Lets give him a proper 'together but apart' farewell and do something positive in his memory.

Tony was a remarkable man who has made a positive difference in the lives of hundreds of people over his 40 years coaching. As the current circumstances will prevent us all from being able to attend any service to say our farewell to a much loved coach it seemed like an excellent opportunity to do something that would allow us all to say farewell in our own way whilst doing something positive in Tony's memory. 


If everyone who was coached by Tony were to complete a swim, run or cycle etc. of a reasonable distance (circumstances permitting) and make a donation towards Cancer Research together we could all have the opportunity to say our own goodbye to him in our own time and whilst doing so and raise money towards a truly meaningful cause in his memory.

I will be setting up a Just Giving page for this cause so we can all see just how much of a positive impact Tony has made through each of us over his career and work as The City of Canterbury S.C team again to give a huge and positive send off despite the current restrictions!

story:
Anybody who had the pleasure of knowing Cazzy, would know that she was a kind hearted, beautiful young lady who would always go that extra mile.

She was the most supportive person I have ever met and she always had time to share a drink and put the world to rights.

Last year Cazzy began to struggle, noticing pains in her legs first, her back and her neck. She had thought that this was just work related, as she (the most loving and caring person in the world) was a carer. She went to the Drs and through physiotherapy to try and do something about the pain, but it wasn't getting any better. Then in June she received a phone call telling her to get to James Cook now for a scan as they had reason to believe it may be cancer. That is a day I will never ever forget. Hayley drove us both to the hospital and I remember wheeling her through to the ward. It was shortly after that, where Cazzy found out the life changing news that she had cancer. In her true style though, she not only decided that she was going to beat it, she was also the one comforting others as she didn't want anyone to be upset!! She had even asked one friend "why are you crying". She was determined to beat it, to get over it and say a big FU to cancer. Unfortunately this was never meant to be, she later found out that her cancer had metastasised - that is the medical word for spread - try to imagine the cancer is like a dandelion, cancer which metastasizes is like a dandelion blowing in the wind.

She had stage 4 Breast Cancer, with Mets. She knew it wasn't curable only treatable, she knew she would not beat the cancer, but she would not let the cancer beat her. Cazzy carried on doing the things she loved, she still went for meals, still met friends for drinks, she rehomed a gorgeous kitty and gave it love right up until she sadly lost her battle on the 20th of November 2020, peacefully in the hospice with family members present.

From conversations with Cazzy I know she would approve of raising money for charity, as charities have helped her and her family and they can help others.

She was also keen on getting people to talk about cancer and to be aware of the signs so that others wouldn't have to go through what she did, because of this I am now going to give you some information from NHS (2018) which is as follows:

CHECK YOUR BREASTS REGULARLY, check the full breast up to the armpit, this can be done when you shower and there are many tutorial videos out there if you are unsure how to do this.

Know what is normal for you, look and feel your breasts!

Look for any changes in size, outline, shape, change in your skin - eg puckering or dimpling, new lump or bumpy area, thickening of the skin, changes in the nipple position, if it is moist or red, if their is any discomfort and or pain around the area. If you are concerned SEE YOUR G.P! if you are not happy, get a second opinion!! 

By sharing my best friends story I hope that people will be more aware and I hope that one day there will be a cure for this horrible thing that took her far too young </3

story:
Peter Michael Meyrick, aged 76, died on Sunday 22nd November, peacefully at Lily House in Ely, Cambridgeshire. 

Peter was born in 1944 and grew up in and around the Chester area, where he met his wife Jean. They were involved locally in amateur dramatics and Peter sang in the choir for the Eaton Estate. Peter worked in sales of optical equipment and optical products the majority of his life and moved around the country, as his job required, whilst residing in Leicestershire, Shropshire, Bedfordshire and Northants. He changed career slightly and worked as a store manager for the Co-Op in the last few years before retirement. 

On retirement and having now lost Jean to cancer, he moved to Cambridgeshire to be closer to his daughter, son in law and two grandsons.

He lived a life full of happiness and joviality and was liked by all that knew him. Her will be very missed in our lives, but would want us to raise a toast to him, preferably with a glass of red and laugh about the times we shared with him.

story:
Instead of sending cards this year we are asking our supporters if they would consider making a donation to Marie Curie.

In return, if you would like an ECard that you can email to your family and friends or post on your social media pages, then email TeamScotland@mariecurie.org.uk and we'll send one to you.

In Scotland, over the two week festive period, Marie Curie will need to raise £500,000 to support our services.

Each donation can make a huge difference.

Our nurses work on the front line, night and day, in people’s homes across the Scotland, providing hands-on care and vital emotional support. If you’re living with a terminal illness, they will help you to feel safe, supported and cared-for in the place where you’re most comfortable. 

They will continue to work over the festive period with many caring for patients on Christmas Eve or Christmas night, or Hogmanay or New Years Day.  

Right now, we’re needed more than ever. We’ve been on the front line, day and night, seven days a week, throughout the pandemic. Our services help people to stay out of hospital, relieving pressure on the system and providing vital care. 

It is crucial that we continue to be there for the people who need us, those living with any terminal illness. 

With your support we can continue to help families facing terminal illness and bereavement right now.

eventName: UCL WASH Art Competition - Human Rights Day
story:
In celebration of Human Rights Day, UCL WASH Society is organising an art competition and fundraiser for WaterAid UK! As well as honouring the continuous efforts for human rights protection around the globe, we want to mark the 10-year anniversary of water and sanitation being formally recognised as vital human rights by the UN General Assembly. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives.
